Variational Inference

Mean Field Approximation

Mixture of Gaussians

From Bishop 2006, we know that for a mixture of gaussians, we can use the following model:

p(X,Z,Π,μ,Λ)=p(X|Z,Π,μ,Λ)p(Z|Π)p(Π)p(μ|Λ)p(Λ)p(X,Z,Π,μ,Λ)=p(X|Z,Π,μ,Λ)p(Z|Π)p(Π)p(μ|Λ)p(Λ)

with conjugate priors distributions:

p(Π)=Dir(Π|α0)p(Π)=Dir(Π|α0)

p(μ|Λ)p(Λ)=p(μ,Λ)=∏k=1K(μk|m0,(β0Λk)−1)(Λk|W0,ν0)p(μ|Λ)p(Λ)=p(μ,Λ)=∏k=1KN(μk|m0,(β0Λk)−1)W(Λk|W0,ν0)

p(Z|Π)=∏n=1N∏k=1KΠznkkp(Z|Π)=∏n=1N∏k=1KΠkznk

p(X|Z,Π,μ,Λ)=∏n=1N∏k=1K(xn|μk,Λ−1)znkp(X|Z,Π,μ,Λ)=∏n=1N∏k=1KN(xn|μk,Λ−1)znk

With the mean field approximation q(Z,Π,μ,Λ)=q(Z)q(Π,μ,Λ)q(Z,Π,μ,Λ)=q(Z)q(Π,μ,Λ) that splits the latent variables from the parameters of the model, iterative update rules, similar to EM can be derived:

Expectation

Approximating the distribution q results in the necessity to compute:

ln(ρnk)=𝔼(ln(Πk))+12𝔼(ln|Λk|)−D2ln(2π)−12𝔼((xn−μk)TΛk(xn−μk))μ,Λln⁡(ρnk)=E(ln⁡(Πk))+12E(ln⁡|Λk|)−D2ln⁡(2π)−12E((xn−μk)TΛk(xn−μk))μ,Λ

to obtain the statistics, for rnk=ρnk∑Kj=1ρnjrnk=ρnk∑j=1Kρnj

Nk=∑n=1NrnkNk=∑n=1Nrnk
xk⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯=1Nk∑n=1Nrnkxnxk¯=1Nk∑n=1Nrnkxn
Sk=1Nk∑n=1Nrnk(xn−xk⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯)(xn−xk⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯)TSk=1Nk∑n=1Nrnk(xn−xk¯)(xn−xk¯)T

The original expression of ρnkρnk might be simplified and allows to directly compute the rnkrnk. By expressing:

ln(Π̃ k)=𝔼(ln(Πk))ln⁡(Π~k)=E(ln⁡(Πk))
ln(Λk~)=𝔼(ln(Λk))ln⁡(Λk~)=E(ln⁡(Λk))

Then

rnk=Πk~Λk~e𝔼((xn−μk)TΛk(xn−μk))μ,ΛCrnk=Πk~Λk~eE((xn−μk)TΛk(xn−μk))μ,ΛC

So if it is possible to derive analytical expressions for non constant elements in this expression, it will be feasible to obtain directly the rnkrnk.

First, according to wikipedia, if Xi∼(α)Xi∼D(α) , then 𝔼(ln(Xi))=ψ(αi)−ψ(∑jαj)E(ln⁡(Xi))=ψ(αi)−ψ(∑jαj) where ψψ is the digamma function. It thus follows that:

ln(Π̃ k)=ψ(αk)−ψ(∑jαj)ln⁡(Π~k)=ψ(αk)−ψ(∑jαj)

Similarly, according to wikipedia again (section Properties/Log-expectation) if X∼(V,n)X∼W(V,n), then 𝔼(ln(Xi))=ψp(n2)+pln(2)+ln|V|E(ln⁡(Xi))=ψp(n2)+pln⁡(2)+ln⁡|V| with ψpψp the multivariate digamma function. wikipedia (section Derivatives) gives ψp(a)=∂logΓp(a)∂a=∑pi=0ψ(a+1−i2)ψp(a)=∂log⁡Γp(a)∂a=∑i=0pψ(a+1−i2). Thus it follows that:

ln(Λk~)=Dln(2)+ln|Wk|+∑i=0Dψ(νk+1−i2)ln⁡(Λk~)=Dln⁡(2)+ln⁡|Wk|+∑i=0Dψ(νk+1−i2)

Finally, it is necessary to also derive an analytical expression for Ek=𝔼((xn−μk)TΛk(xn−μk))μ,ΛEk=E((xn−μk)TΛk(xn−μk))μ,Λ.

First, it is important to notice that in the general case xTΣx=tr(xTΣx)=tr(ΣxxT)xTΣx=tr(xTΣx)=tr(ΣxxT), thus, using the factorization q∗(μk,Λk)=q∗(μk|Λk)q∗(Λk)q∗(μk,Λk)=q∗(μk|Λk)q∗(Λk):

Ek=∫∫tr(Λk(xn−μk)(xn−μk)T)q∗(μk|Λk)q∗(Λk)dμkdΛkEk=∫∫tr(Λk(xn−μk)(xn−μk)T)q∗(μk|Λk)q∗(Λk)dμkdΛk

We furthermore know that q∗(μk|Λk)∼(μk|mk,(βkΛk)−1)q∗(μk|Λk)∼N(μk|mk,(βkΛk)−1), and thus it follows that

𝔼(μk)=mkE(μk)=mk

and also, from the matrix cookbook (page 35, equation (321)) that

𝔼(μkμTk)=mkmTk+(βkΛk)−1E(μkμkT)=mkmkT+(βkΛk)−1

and therefore:

𝔼((xn−μk)(xn−μk)T)=𝔼(xnxTn−μkxTn−μkxTn+μkμTk)=(xn−mk)(xn−mk)T+(βkΛk)−1E((xn−μk)(xn−μk)T)=E(xnxnT−μkxnT−μkxnT+μkμkT)=(xn−mk)(xn−mk)T+(βkΛk)−1

Thus by linearity (is it actually linearity ?) of the expected value and of the trace:

Ek=∫tr[Λk((xn−mk)(xn−mk)T+(βkΛk)−1)]q∗(Λk)dΛkEk=∫tr[Λk((xn−mk)(xn−mk)T+(βkΛk)−1)]q∗(Λk)dΛk

=Dβk+∫tr(Λk((xn−mk)(xn−mk)T)q∗(Λk)dΛk=Dβk+∫tr(Λk((xn−mk)(xn−mk)T)q∗(Λk)dΛk

=Dβk+∫((xn−mk)TΛk(xn−mk))q∗(Λk)dΛk=Dβk+∫((xn−mk)TΛk(xn−mk))q∗(Λk)dΛk

which finally yields, as 𝔼(Λk)=νkWkE(Λk)=νkWk

=Dβk+νk(xn−mk)TWk(xn−mk)=Dβk+νk(xn−mk)TWk(xn−mk)

Normalizing Flows

Finite Flows

Considering invertible smooth mappings f:ℝd→ℝdf:Rd→Rd, the mapping of a random variable zz with distribution q(z)q(z) will result in a new random variable z′=f(z)z′=f(z) which follows the distribution :

q(z′)=q(z)|det∂f−1∂z′|=q(z)|det∂f∂z|−1q(z′)=q(z)|det∂f−1∂z′|=q(z)|det∂f∂z|−1

The right equality is the inverse function theorem

Thus for a succession of k mappings:

zK=fK∘…∘f1(z0)zK=fK∘…∘f1(z0)
ln(qK(zK)=ln(q0(z0))−∑k=1Kln|det∂fk∂zk−1|ln⁡(qK(zK)=ln⁡(q0(z0))−∑k=1Kln⁡|det∂fk∂zk−1|

Exemple in 1D: Let z0∼qo(z0)z0∼qo(z0) and z1∼q1(z1)z1∼q1(z1) such that z1=f(z0)z1=f(z0) with f invertible and smooth such that f−1(z1)=z0f−1(z1)=z0. It can be seen as a change of variables, for which the differential area must be invariant under change of variables.

Therefore,

q1(z1)=q0(z0)|dz0dz1|=q0(z0)|df−1(z1)dz1|q1(z1)=q0(z0)|dz0dz1|=q0(z0)|df−1(z1)dz1|

Which in turns, thanks to the inverse function theorem yields:

q1(z1)=q0(z0)|df(z0)dz0|−1q1(z1)=q0(z0)|df(z0)dz0|−1

note: absolute value of f can be considered to make sure its rate of change is positive.

Planar Flows

Planar Flow Derivation

Considering a family of transformations:

f(z)=z+uh(wTz+b)f(z)=z+uh(wTz+b)

where hh is a smooth element-wise non-linearity. Then it is possible to derive, through the chain rule

|det∂f∂z|=|det(∂z∂z+uT∂h(wTz+b)∂z)|=|det(I+uTh′(wTz+b)∂(wTz+b)∂)|=|det(I+uTh′(wTz+b)w)||det∂f∂z|=|det(∂z∂z+uT∂h(wTz+b)∂z)|=|det(I+uTh′(wTz+b)∂(wTz+b)∂)|=|det(I+uTh′(wTz+b)w)|

which in turn yields, through the matrix determinant lemma, with the notation ψ(z)=h′(wTz+b)wψ(z)=h′(wTz+b)w

|det∂f∂z|=|(1+uTψ(z))det(I)|=|1+uTψ(z)||det∂f∂z|=|(1+uTψ(z))det(I)|=|1+uTψ(z)|

note: why the transpose act like this? [-> eq (69), page 10 of matrix cookbook cf ∂wTz∂z=∂∑iwizi∂z=∑iwiei=w∂wTz∂z=∂∑iwizi∂z=∑iwiei=w] And why ∂z∂z=I∂z∂z=I ? [-> Implicit notation of Jacobian]

Radial Flows

Radial Flow Derivation

Considering a family of transformations:

f(z)=z+βh(α,r)(z−z0)f(z)=z+βh(α,r)(z−z0)

where r=||z−zo||r=||z−zo|| and h(α,r)=1α+rh(α,r)=1α+r

It is posible to derive

|det∂f∂z|=|det(∂z∂z+β∂h(α,r)∂z(z−z0)T+βh(α,r)∂z∂z)|=|det((1+βh(α,r))I+β∂h(α,r)∂z)(z−z0)T||det∂f∂z|=|det(∂z∂z+β∂h(α,r)∂z(z−z0)T+βh(α,r)∂z∂z)|=|det((1+βh(α,r))I+β∂h(α,r)∂z)(z−z0)T|

From the matrix cookbook, equation (129), it can be infered that ∂r∂z=∂||z−z0||∂z=z−z0||z−z0||∂r∂z=∂||z−z0||∂z=z−z0||z−z0||. The chain rule then gives ∂h(α,r)∂z=h′(α,r)∂r∂z=h′(α,r)z−z0||z−z0||∂h(α,r)∂z=h′(α,r)∂r∂z=h′(α,r)z−z0||z−z0||. Finally, it follows that ∂h(α,r)∂z(z−z0)T=h′(α,r)z−z0||z−z0||(z−z0)T∂h(α,r)∂z(z−z0)T=h′(α,r)z−z0||z−z0||(z−z0)T. The jacobian ∂h(α,r)∂z)(z−z0)T∂h(α,r)∂z)(z−z0)T therefore has rank one and can be diagonalized into

∂h(α,r)∂z(z−z0)T=[r0⋯0 00⋯0 ⋱⋱⋮⋱00⋯0 ]∂h(α,r)∂z(z−z0)T=[r0⋯0 00⋯0 ⋱⋱⋮⋱00⋯0 ]

which yields:

|det∂f∂z|=[1+βh(α,r)]d−1[1+βh(α,r)+βh′(α,r)r]|det∂f∂z|=[1+βh(α,r)]d−1[1+βh(α,r)+βh′(α,r)r]

Evaluating Variational Inference

Examples

1D

We consider a model with a single parameter θθ:

yi=θ2i+ϵiyi=θi2+ϵi

Where ϵi∼(0,σ2)ϵi∼N(0,σ2), which means that yi|θi∼(θ2i,σ2)yi|θi∼N(θi2,σ2)

It will be assumed that theta is sampled from a univariate gaussian prior:

θ∼(0,1)θ∼N(0,1)

By Bayes theorem, the true posterior can be expressed:

p(θi|yi)∝p(yi|θi)p(θi)=(yi|θ2i,σ2)(θi|0,1)p(θi|yi)∝p(yi|θi)p(θi)=N(yi|θi2,σ2)N(θi|0,1)

The following is obtained for y=0.5y=0.5, σ2=0.1σ2=0.1

2D

Figure Eight

Let’s consider a mixture of gaussians with a 2D parameter vector θθ sampled from an improper uniform prior.

θ∼θ∼U

Considering a gaussian mixture likelihood:

p(y|θ)=0.5(θ|μ1,Σ)+0.5(θ|μ2,Σ)p(y|θ)=0.5N(θ|μ1,Σ)+0.5N(θ|μ2,Σ)

Then the posterior is also a mixture of gaussians:

p(θ|y)∝p(y|θ)=0.5(θ|μ1,Σ)+0.5(θ|μ2,Σ)p(θ|y)∝p(y|θ)=0.5N(θ|μ1,Σ)+0.5N(θ|μ2,Σ)

illustrated in the following figure:

The two following figures illustrate how the flows warp the initial distribution to fit the posterior more closely. The original gaussian, q0q0, when sampled, generates the following set of points

While after the flows, the resulting distribution qkqk, generates:

Eight Schools

The Eight Schools model is the simplest Bayesian hierarchical normal model. Given a set of schools in which a treatment is tested, each of them has to report the mean effect of the treatment yiyi and its associated standard deviation σiσi. All treatments are supposed independent from each other.

The following model postulates that the mean effect of treatment yiyi is sampled from a normal distribution centered around the true latent mean effect of the treatment, θiθi:

yi|θi∼(θi,σ2i)yi|θi∼N(θi,σi2)

These latent mean effect of treatment are themselves sampled from a shared normal distribution (the same treatment being tested in different schools) with parameters μμ and ττ:

θi|μ,τ∼(μ,τ2)θi|μ,τ∼N(μ,τ2)

Such that the parameters themselves have priors

μ∼(0,5)μ∼N(0,5)
τ∼Half-Cauchy(0,5)τ∼Half-Cauchy(0,5)

Representing the model as a graphical model can be useful to understand the model.

Indeed, it makes it obvious that

p(yi,θi,σi,μ,τ)=p(yi|θi,σi)p(θi|μ,τ)p(μ)p(τ)=(yi|θi,σ2i)(θi|μ,τ2)(μ|0,5)Half-Cauchy(τ|0,5)p(yi,θi,σi,μ,τ)=p(yi|θi,σi)p(θi|μ,τ)p(μ)p(τ)=N(yi|θi,σi2)N(θi|μ,τ2)N(μ|0,5)Half-Cauchy(τ|0,5)

And thus the posterior distribution can be formulated as:

p(θi,μ,τ|yi,σi)∝p(yi|θi,σi)p(θi|μ,τ)p(μ)p(τ)=(yi|θi,σ2i)(θi|μ,τ2)(μ|0,5)Half-Cauchy(τ|0,5)p(θi,μ,τ|yi,σi)∝p(yi|θi,σi)p(θi|μ,τ)p(μ)p(τ)=N(yi|θi,σi2)N(θi|μ,τ2)N(μ|0,5)Half-Cauchy(τ|0,5)

In the case of standard variational inference, the approximated posterior will be:

θi,μ,τ∼(m,Σ)θi,μ,τ∼N(m,Σ)

The following figure shows the learned distributions for the latent variable θθ and the parameters μμ and ττ

And the following displays the scatter of samples from q for log(τ)log(τ) (x-axis) and θθ (y-axis):

Using normalizing flows allows a closer fit, especially because it allows the original gaussian approximating ττ to fit the true half-cauchy prior very closely. As can be seen in the following:

Unanswered Questions

  • Why does Bishop say that the variance of q(z)q(z) is controlled by the direction of smalles variance of p(z)p(z)? (page 467 in the paragraph after equation (10.15)) 🆗

I implemented my own version of that mean field approxmation, and it results that the approximated posterior q(z) has variance:

Var(q(z))=[Λ110 0Λ22]Var(q(z))=[Λ110 0Λ22]
Resulting in the following distributions:

My mistake was coming from the use of the precision matrix. In bishop ΛΛ is the precision matrix (i.e Σ=Λ−1Σ=Λ−1). Therefore considering:

q(z)=q1(z1)q2(z2)=(z1|m1,Λ−111)(z2|m2,Λ−122)q(z)=q1(z1)q2(z2)=N(z1|m1,Λ11−1)N(z2|m2,Λ22−1)

is equivalent to having q(z)=(z|m,Σ)q(z)=N(z|m,Σ) with:

Σ=[1Λ110 01Λ22]Σ=[1Λ110 01Λ22]

where Λ11Λ11 is the element at indices 1,1 in the precision matrix. It gives the resulting result:

  • How can one draw the contour plot of a mixture of multivariate gaussians in mean field approximation?

The parameters of the different mixture elements have a known distribution (see the first part for that), but how can one use the following ?

p(μ|Λ)p(Λ)=p(μ,Λ)=∏k=1K(μk|m0,(β0Λk)−1)(Λk|W0,ν0)p(μ|Λ)p(Λ)=p(μ,Λ)=∏k=1KN(μk|m0,(β0Λk)−1)W(Λk|W0,ν0)
In my implementation, I cannot access directly the Wishart component ΛkΛk.

  • What dataset will be used for testing the neural network implementation ?

First some test distributions can be used to verify the ability of the flow to fit non-trivial distributions. Then, it would be useful to use a broad dataset to train a VAE where the encoder is enriched with normalizing flows (ex CIFAR10?).

  • What non-trivial distributions could be used to test the ability of a finite set of flows to fit? 🆗

Yes but did it work? presents a way to conduct a diagnostic of how close an approximated posterior distribtion fits, but I am not sure yet on what to use from that. Otherwise I implemented a banana distribution and a circle distribution.

  • Are there any other types of finite flow we could consider?

After going through relevant conferences from ICML Normalizing Flow Workshop, no type of other flow was discussed, only some extension of planar flow presented here video, paper

  • Is there a way to prove that the planar flow for example results in a normalized distribution? 🆗

To show that it is the case, one would need to prove ∫inf−infq1(z1)dz1=1∫−infinfq1(z1)dz1=1

From the definition, for a single planar flow,

∫inf−infq1(z1)dz1=∫inf−infq0(f−1(z1))|1+uTh′(wTf−1(z1)+b)w|−1dz1∫−infinfq1(z1)dz1=∫−infinfq0(f−1(z1))|1+uTh′(wTf−1(z1)+b)w|−1dz1

It would therefore be necessary for that approach to know f−1f−1, which is not trivial to find for e.g h(x)=tanh(x)h(x)=tanh(x).

So in a specific case it’s analytically difficult to prove that. But in general, because of how we defined q1 the following holds:

∫inf−infq1(z1)dz1=∫inf−infq1(z1)dz1dz0dz0=∫inf−infq1(z1)f′(z0)dz0=∫inf−infq0(z0)dz0=1∫−infinfq1(z1)dz1=∫−infinfq1(z1)dz1dz0dz0=∫−infinfq1(z1)f′(z0)dz0=∫−infinfq0(z0)dz0=1

  • For learning a given distribution, what loss can be used for optimization of flow parameters?

The variational free energy can be used, if one can infer the negative log likelihood of the data and provide a prior for the latent variables.

  • If these flows are used in the setting of a VAE, what kind of loss can be used?

Basic VAE uses ELBO.
